texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My workday takes me from email to terminals to browsers to documents. I love tiling window managers because they keep me organized and less distracted. Many are less resource-intensive as well.
texts.text: My workday takes me from email to terminals to browsers to documents. I love tiling window managers because they keep me organized and less distracted. Many are less resource-intensive as well.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Although  i3  has graced my displays for years now (and I've  written many posts about it ), I recently picked up an AMD graphics card and made my way to  sway .
texts.text: Although  i3  has graced my displays for years now (and I've  written many posts about it ), I recently picked up an AMD graphics card and made my way to  sway .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The biggest difference between the two is that sway runs on  Wayland  rather than X. Sway has control over how nearly everything works, such as input devices, displays, backgrounds, and more. If you were frustrated with lots of hacks in i3 for various X-related things, you might enjoy sway.
texts.text: The biggest difference between the two is that sway runs on  Wayland  rather than X. Sway has control over how nearly everything works, such as input devices, displays, backgrounds, and more. If you were frustrated with lots of hacks in i3 for various X-related things, you might enjoy sway.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Much of my early experience with sway involves this process:
texts.text: Much of my early experience with sway involves this process:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Scrunch my face and say "Well, that's not quite right."
texts.text: Scrunch my face and say "Well, that's not quite right."

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Fortunately, sway puts up with my constant reloads of the configuration until one day when I changed lots of configuration items and suddenly every reload caused Firefox to crash. My primary version of Firefox is the  Developer Edition  (currently 101.0b9), but I also keep a stable version of Firefox (version 100) around that Fedora provides.
texts.text: Fortunately, sway puts up with my constant reloads of the configuration until one day when I changed lots of configuration items and suddenly every reload caused Firefox to crash. My primary version of Firefox is the  Developer Edition  (currently 101.0b9), but I also keep a stable version of Firefox (version 100) around that Fedora provides.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I started up the default Fedora version of Firefox, reloaded the configuration in sway, and the stable Firefox crashed, too. 🔥
texts.text: I started up the default Fedora version of Firefox, reloaded the configuration in sway, and the stable Firefox crashed, too. 🔥

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Nothing appeared on the screen when Firefox crashed. The window just disappeared and my terminal filled up the screen where Firefox was. I could reproduce the crash multiple times with both versions of Firefox. The crash kept occurring even after a reboot.
texts.text: Nothing appeared on the screen when Firefox crashed. The window just disappeared and my terminal filled up the screen where Firefox was. I could reproduce the crash multiple times with both versions of Firefox. The crash kept occurring even after a reboot.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When I ran either version of Firefox from the command line, I finally got some error output:
texts.text: When I ran either version of Firefox from the command line, I finally got some error output:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
Lost connection to Wayland compositor.
Exiting due to channel error.
Exiting due to channel error.
Exiting due to channel error.
Exiting due to channel error.

Exiting due to channel error.
Exiting due to channel error.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Hmm, it looks like Firefox can't talk to Sway for a moment and that might cause the crash. But why did this suddenly start happening?
texts.text: Hmm, it looks like Firefox can't talk to Sway for a moment and that might cause the crash. But why did this suddenly start happening?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I gradually backed out the recent sway configuration changes and finally found the configuration involved in the crash:
texts.text: I gradually backed out the recent sway configuration changes and finally found the configuration involved in the crash:

texts.label: code
paragraph
texts.orig: If I removed that section, Firefox stopped crashing on sway config reloads. If I put it back in, Firefox crashed.
texts.text: If I removed that section, Firefox stopped crashing on sway config reloads. If I put it back in, Firefox crashed.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Armed with an error message and a method for reproducing my crash, I set off to use the most powerful system administrator tool on the market: Google. 😜
texts.text: Armed with an error message and a method for reproducing my crash, I set off to use the most powerful system administrator tool on the market: Google. 😜

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I landed on  Mozilla Bug 1652820  where other Firefox users noted that sway config reloads caused crashes for them, too. A user noted  further down in the bug  that if they removed the
texts.text: I landed on  Mozilla Bug 1652820  where other Firefox users noted that sway config reloads caused crashes for them, too. A user noted  further down in the bug  that if they removed the

texts.orig: configuration and specified the actual device identifier, the problem went away.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 🐙  Have multiple keyboards or input devices?  Other users noted in the bug report that the crash will happen again (even with specific identifiers) if you have two keyboards and both keyboards are connected. If you run into this problem, another user shared their workaround  using
texts.text: 🐙  Have multiple keyboards or input devices?  Other users noted in the bug report that the crash will happen again (even with specific identifiers) if you have two keyboards and both keyboards are connected. If you run into this problem, another user shared their workaround  using
